text.headline:
From Turing to Transformers:
The Story of Machine Learning
text.text: A timeline of bold ideas, breakthroughs, and turning points that shaped machine learning from its early theories in the 1950s to today’s generative AI revolution.

media.caption: Alan Turing, father of theoretical computer science and AI.

text.headline: Turing Asks: Can Machines Think?
text.text: Alan Turing poses a bold question in 1950: Can machines think? To explore this, he introduces the Turing Test, a simple yet profound challenge—if a computer can convincingly imitate human conversation, does that make it intelligent? This thought experiment ignites decades of AI and machine learning research.

media.caption: Frank Rosenblatt working on the Perceptron.

text.headline: The Perceptron Plants the Seed
text.text: Frank Rosenblatt unveils the Perceptron—a primitive neural network that learns to recognize patterns. Though limited, it stirs excitement that machines might one day rival human learning, planting the seeds for modern deep learning decades ahead of its time.

text.headline: Learning by Comparison: Nearest Neighbor
text.text: In 1967, the Nearest Neighbor algorithm shows a new way for machines to learn: by comparing data points. Instead of rules hand-written by humans, computers begin making decisions based on similarity. This marks an early step toward learning from examples.

text.headline: Backpropagation Brings Neural Nets Back
text.text: Geoffrey Hinton and collaborators breathe new life into neural networks with backpropagation, a training method that makes multilayer networks practical. Suddenly, machines can learn more complex patterns, reviving interest in a field many had written off as a dead end.

media.caption: IBM’s Deep Blue vs. Garry Kasparov.

text.headline: Deep Blue Conquers Chess
text.text: In 1997, IBM’s Deep Blue stuns the world by defeating chess grandmaster Garry Kasparov. While more brute-force search than true learning, the victory becomes a cultural milestone—machines are no longer just calculators, but challengers in intellectual arenas once thought untouchable.

media.caption: Geoffrey Hinton – the 'Godfather of Deep Learning.'

text.headline: The Deep Learning Revolution Begins
text.text: Geoffrey Hinton and colleagues spark the Deep Learning Revolution by showing how multilayer neural networks can crack problems long thought unsolvable. From speech recognition to computer vision, deep learning becomes the new driving force behind AI progress.

text.headline: AlexNet Ignites the AI Boom
text.text: In 2012, Alex Krizhevsky, Ilya Sutskever, and Geoffrey Hinton unleash AlexNet, a deep convolutional neural network that crushes the ImageNet competition by a staggering margin. Its success proves that GPUs and deep neural networks can outperform traditional methods, igniting the modern wave of AI breakthroughs in vision, speech, and beyond.

text.headline: AlphaGo’s Historic Victory
text.text: In a historic 2016 match, DeepMind’s AlphaGo defeats legendary Go champion Lee Sedol—winning 4 out of 5 games. Go, long considered beyond the reach of machines due to its astronomical complexity, falls to deep reinforcement learning and neural networks. The victory stuns the world, marking a new era where AI challenges human intuition and creativity.

text.headline: BERT Teaches Machines Context
text.text: Google introduces BERT, a transformer-based language model that revolutionizes natural language processing. For the first time, machines grasp context and nuance in human sentences, powering massive leaps in search, translation, and conversational AI.

text.headline: The Age of Generative AI
text.text: The rise of large-scale AI models like GPT, DALL·E, and other generative systems marks a new era. AI is now part of everyday life, powering chatbots, creative tools, and automation across industries.
